title: Why Is the music industry very competitive and cutthroat? - Quora

response.answer_text: You have a band but so do hundreds of other people. There’s only one measure for success; a dying business model people still put a phony value on as we speak. That’s the whole big label, big contract thing. Every band on the planet would love to have that contract but what they don’t understand is that you have to have something that stands out and, on a long enough timeline, it’s going to become irrelevant unless you do something groundbreaking. That “something groundbreaking”…yeah, fuck your definition of it because, unless it is something that generates obscene amounts of goddamn cash, it’s not “something groundbreaking.” This is why the music industry is kinda dying at the moment. Actually, it’s kinda lingering in some hideous proto-life on life support. Put simply, it’s the way it is because labels have become overinflated, sorta like movie studios. You have only two types; Fucking Colossal Gargantuan Behemoths that only want to get bigger and indie labels. Fact is, some indie labels might have far better music than the Behemoths but some of us will never know that because the indies may never really get any airplay and, should they manage that minor miracle, they’ll never get to heavy rotation. It’s a network. You’re either in it or you’re not. There’s a whole lotta legalese in there too to keep people’s asses covered. Guess who doesn’t have the coverage necessary? You do. You make cents off of your albums and you will make most of your money from merchandising and ticket sales from concerts. The bigger the turnout, the more you will make. The more you make, the more music you will probably need to churn out to support another tour and hope like shit you have the budget to make all the dates. It’s the structure of it coupled by attorneys who are basically serving two masters here. First, you have to keep everything legal. All money has to be accounted for in order to make sure everything is on the up and up with taxes. Second, you have to ensure your corporate overlords get paid and paid comfortably. Then there’s the X-Factor; The fact that the music business (much like everything in the entire entertainment industry) is a huge gamble. Let’s say that you have a contract, finally. You scored that ever-elusive key to the door of your dreams. You had better be very entertaining. You better come up with something original on the regular. Because if you don’t and that gamble taken on your doesn’t net huge returns, you could be released from that contract. Remember, the attorneys will work for the company, not you. Switch roles. If you’ve just dumped about a few million into a band and it’s not paying off, what would you do? That’s why it’s so cut throat.
